title: The controversial origins of the Encyclopedia - Addison Anderson

multiple-choice.question: Why was Denis Diderot imprisoned in 1749?

options.label: A
options.text: For writing a pornographic novel

options.label: B
options.text: For translating English texts without permission

options.label: C
options.text: For authoring an essay about a philosopher's deathbed rejection of God

options.label: D
options.text: For publishing a book on anatomy

multiple-choice.question: Who commissioned Denis Diderot to adapt the English cyclopedia for French subscribers?

options.label: A
options.text: Jean le Rond d'Alembert

options.label: B
options.text: Francis Bacon

options.label: C
options.text: Louis de Jaucourt

options.label: D
options.text: Andr√© le Breton

multiple-choice.question: Who wrote the famous preliminary discourse for the encyclopedia?

options.label: A
options.text: Denis Diderot

options.label: B
options.text: Jean Jacques Rousseau

options.label: C
options.text: Louis de Jaucourt

options.label: D
options.text: Jean le Rond d'Alembert

multiple-choice.question: What was the main idea of the French Enlightenment as championed by the preliminary discourse?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of commerce and technology

options.label: B
options.text: The divine right of kings

options.label: C
options.text: Independent investigative reasoning as the path to progress

options.label: D
options.text: The power of imagination

multiple-choice.question: What three-part system did Diderot adapt from Francis Bacon's "Classification of Knowledge" to organize the encyclopedia?

options.label: A
options.text: Commerce, Technology, and Crafts

options.label: B
options.text: Arts, Sciences, and Crafts

options.label: C
options.text: History, Elegance, and Fire

options.label: D
options.text: Memory, Reason, and Imagination

multiple-choice.question: How many entries did Louis de Jaucourt contribute to the encyclopedia?
What was the consequence of Diderot's entry on "political authority" in the encyclopedia?

options.label: A
options.text: It supported the divine right of kings

options.label: B
options.text: It was neutral on the topic of monarchy

options.label: C
options.text: It dismantled the divine right of kings

options.label: D
options.text: It argued for the importance of commerce and technology

multiple-choice.question: What happened to Louis de Jaucourt's book on anatomy?

options.label: A
options.text: It was published in France

options.label: B
options.text: It was published in Amsterdam

options.label: C
options.text: The ship carrying the manuscript sank

options.label: D
options.text: It was never completed

multiple-choice.question: Why did Pope Clement XIII declare readers of the encyclopedia excommunicated?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it was written in French

options.label: B
options.text: Because it challenged the Catholic Church's authority

options.label: C
options.text: Because it was deemed "dangerous" and "reprehensible"

options.label: D
options.text: Because it contained recipes

multiple-choice.question: According to the text, why did Pope Clement XIII declare readers of the encyclopedia excommunicated, using which specific words to describe it?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it was written in French, and "heretical"

options.label: B
options.text: Because it challenged the Catholic Church's authority, and "blasphemous"

options.label: C
options.text: Because it was deemed "dangerous", "reprehensible", and written in the "most seductive style"

options.label: D
options.text: Because it contained recipes, and "obscene"

multiple-choice.question: What was the ultimate fate of the uncensored pages of the encyclopedia?

options.label: A
options.text: They were destroyed

options.label: B
options.text: They were published in France

options.label: C
options.text: They were lost forever

options.label: D
options.text: They reappeared in Russia in 1933

title: The science of skin color - Angela Koine Flynn

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary factor responsible for the variation in skin color among humans?

options.label: A
options.text: Genetics

options.label: B
options.text: Environmental factors

options.label: C
options.text: Diet and lifestyle

options.label: D
options.text: Exposure to UV sunlight

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of melanin in the skin?

options.label: A
options.text: To regulate body temperature

options.label: B
options.text: To produce skin pigmentation

options.label: C
options.text: To absorb UV light and stimulate vitamin D production

options.label: D
options.text: To shield cells from damage caused by UV light

multiple-choice.question: How did humans adapt to the Sun's UV-carrying rays in the tropical zone?

options.label: A
options.text: By developing lighter skin

options.label: B
options.text: By migrating to a different region

options.label: C
options.text: By using protective clothing

options.label: D
options.text: By producing more melanin to shield cells from damage

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between UV light and the production of vitamin D in the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: UV light blocks vitamin D production

options.label: B
options.text: UV light has no effect on vitamin D production

options.label: C
options.text: Vitamin D blocks UV light

options.label: D
options.text: UV light stimulates vitamin D production

multiple-choice.question: Why did humans with lighter skin have an advantage in regions with limited sunlight?

options.label: A
options.text: They were more protected from melanoma

options.label: B
options.text: They were more resistant to UV light

options.label: C
options.text: They had a genetic predisposition to stronger bones

options.label: D
options.text: They were better able to produce vitamin D due to increased UV absorption

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of generations of selection in humans with lighter skin in regions with limited sunlight?

options.label: A
options.text: Their skin darkened

options.label: B
options.text: Their skin remained the same

options.label: C
options.text: They developed a new trait unrelated to skin color

options.label: D
options.text: Their skin lightened to adapt to the reduced UV light

multiple-choice.question: What does skin color primarily represent in humans?

options.label: A
options.text: A reflection of character

options.label: B
options.text: A reflection of cultural background

options.label: C
options.text: A reflection of genetic makeup

options.label: D
options.text: An adaptive response to the environment, specifically UV light exposure

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the function of rhodopsin in the skin?

options.label: A
options.text: To block UV light

options.label: B
options.text: To absorb UV light

options.label: C
options.text: To stimulate the production of vitamin D

options.label: D
options.text: To stimulate the production of melanin in response to UV light

multiple-choice.question: How did humans cope with the damaging effects of UV light in the past?

options.label: A
options.text: By using sunscreen

options.label: B
options.text: By migrating to a different region

options.label: C
options.text: By producing more melanin as a natural sunscreen

options.label: D
options.text: By developing lighter skin

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between melanoma and UV light damage?

options.label: A
options.text: UV light prevents melanoma

options.label: B
options.text: UV light directly causes melanoma

options.label: C
options.text: Melanoma is caused by a genetic mutation unrelated to UV light

options.label: D
options.text: UV light damages the DNA, which can lead to melanoma if the damage is severe

title: How to speak so that people want to listen

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary issue with the seven deadly sins of speaking, according to the author?

options.label: A
options.text: They make people less likely to listen to us

options.label: B
options.text: They hinder effective communication and lead to misunderstandings

options.label: C
options.text: They make our speech less engaging and boring

options.label: D
options.text: They are only relevant in formal speaking situations

multiple-choice.question: What word do the four cornerstones of powerful speech spell, and what does it mean in this context?

options.label: A
options.text: Hail, to speak loudly and confidently

options.label: B
options.text: Hail, to greet or acclaim enthusiastically

options.label: C
options.text: Talk, to communicate effectively

options.label: D
options.text: Speak, to express oneself clearly

multiple-choice.question: According to the author, what is the definition of the word "hail" in the context of powerful speech?

options.label: A
options.text: To speak in a loud and authoritative voice

options.label: B
options.text: To greet or acclaim enthusiastically

options.label: C
options.text: To listen carefully and attentively

options.label: D
options.text: To write a letter or send a message

multiple-choice.question: What does the author suggest we do to improve the power of our speaking?

options.label: A
options.text: Practice speaking in front of a mirror to improve our body language

options.label: B
options.text: Use more complex vocabulary to sound more intelligent

options.label: C
options.text: Open our toolbox of speaking skills and use the tools available, such as register, timbre, and prosody

options.label: D
options.text: Speak more quickly to convey confidence and authority

multiple-choice.question: What term refers to the way your voice feels to the listener?

options.label: A
options.text: Register

options.label: B
options.text: Timbre

options.label: C
options.text: Prosody

options.label: D
options.text: Pace

multiple-choice.question: What term refers to the sing-song or meta-language we use to impart meaning in conversation?

options.label: A
options.text: Prosody

options.label: B
options.text: Register

options.label: C
options.text: Timbre

options.label: D
options.text: Pitch

multiple-choice.question: What does the author suggest we do to improve our speaking skills, especially before an important talk or conversation?

options.label: A
options.text: Practice speaking in front of a large audience to build confidence

options.label: B
options.text: Use a voice coach to improve our speaking skills and address any issues

options.label: C
options.text: Do vocal warm-up exercises to prepare our voice and improve our delivery

options.label: D
options.text: Speak more slowly and deliberately to convey authority and confidence

multiple-choice.question: What term refers to the act of imposing our sound on others carelessly and inconsiderately?

options.label: A
options.text: Sodcasting

options.label: B
options.text: Speaking loudly and confidently

options.label: C
options.text: Using a microphone or loudspeaker

options.label: D
options.text: Engaging in conversation without listening to others

multiple-choice.question: According to the author, what would the world be like if we spoke powerfully to people who listened consciously in environments that were fit for purpose?

options.label: A
options.text: A world where people would be more likely to disagree and argue

options.label: B
options.text: A world where people would be more likely to ignore each other and disengage

options.label: C
options.text: A world where understanding would be the norm, and people would communicate effectively

options.label: D
options.text: A world where people would be more likely to shout at each other and engage in conflict

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's final point about the importance of speaking powerfully?

options.label: A
options.text: That speaking powerfully is only necessary in formal speaking situations

options.label: B
options.text: That speaking powerfully is only necessary for public speaking and presentations

options.label: C
options.text: That speaking powerfully is essential for effective communication and understanding in all situations

options.label: D
options.text: That speaking powerfully is not necessary for effective communication and can be ignored

title: Every kid needs a champion - Rita Pierson

multiple-choice.question: What has been the primary focus of the speaker's life and work?

options.label: A
options.text: Research and development in education

options.label: B
options.text: Teaching and education reform

options.label: C
options.text: Policy-making in education

options.label: D
options.text: Student counseling and guidance

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is a crucial factor in a child's ability to learn, which is often overlooked in discussions about education reform?

options.label: A
options.text: Socioeconomic status

options.label: B
options.text: Parental involvement

options.label: C
options.text: Teacher-student relationship

options.label: D
options.text: Curriculum design

multiple-choice.question: The speaker quotes Stephen Covey, saying that we should "seek first to understand" in order to build relationships with students. What does this approach entail?

options.label: A
options.text: Focusing on discipline and authority

options.label: B
options.text: Trying to understand students before being understood

options.label: C
options.text: Using rewards and punishments

options.label: D
options.text: Ignoring student needs and emotions

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's goal in using the phrase "I am somebody" with her students, and how does she hope it will impact them?

options.label: A
options.text: To boost her own ego

options.label: B
options.text: To encourage students to take risks

options.label: C
options.text: To increase student self-esteem and confidence

options.label: D
options.text: To promote academic achievement only

multiple-choice.question: How does the speaker respond to a student who missed 18 questions on a quiz, and what message does she hope to convey?

options.label: A
options.text: She gives the student an F and tells them they need to try harder

options.label: B
options.text: She puts a "+2" on the student's paper and a smiley face to emphasize progress

options.label: C
options.text: She ignores the student's performance and moves on

options.label: D
options.text: She calls the student's parents to discuss their child's failure

multiple-choice.question: What approach did the speaker's mother take to teaching and supporting students, and how did it impact them?

options.label: A
options.text: She was strict and focused on discipline

options.label: B
options.text: She took the time to review and support students individually, showing genuine care and concern

options.label: C
options.text: She ignored student needs and focused on academics only

options.label: D
options.text: She was uninvolved and let others handle student support

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's message to educators about their role and responsibilities, and how can they make a positive impact on students?

options.label: A
options.text: That teaching is a thankless job and should be avoided

options.label: B
options.text: That educators should focus on policy and not teaching

options.label: C
options.text: That teaching and learning should bring joy, and educators have the power to make a difference

options.label: D
options.text: That educators should prioritize their own interests above student needs

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the key to a child's success, and how can educators support this?

options.label: A
options.text: Having a good education

options.label: B
options.text: Having a supportive adult in their life who believes in them

options.label: C
options.text: Having a high socioeconomic status

options.label: D
options.text: Being naturally talented

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's message about the importance of relationships in education, and how can educators prioritize these relationships?

options.label: A
options.text: That relationships are not important and should be ignored

options.label: B
options.text: That relationships are only important for students who struggle

options.label: C
options.text: That relationships are crucial for student learning and success, and educators should prioritize building genuine connections

options.label: D
options.text: That relationships are only important for teachers who like their students

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's final message to educators, and what encouragement does she offer?

options.label: A
options.text: That teaching is impossible and should be given up

options.label: B
options.text: That educators have the power to make a difference and should continue to teach and learn with passion and dedication

options.label: C
options.text: That educators should focus on policy and not teaching

options.label: D
options.text: That educators should prioritize their own interests above student needs

title: How to make your writing funnier - Cheri Steinkellner

multiple-choice.question: Which ancient Greek philosopher is attributed to the theory that "The secret to humor is surprise"?

options.label: A
options.text: Plato

options.label: B
options.text: Socrates

options.label: C
options.text: Aristotle

options.label: D
options.text: Epicurus

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the Italian comedy that originated in the late Renaissance and features stock characters like the know-it-all and the loveable loser?

options.label: A
options.text: Commedia Italiana

options.label: B
options.text: Commedia Dell'Arte

options.label: C
options.text: Commedia Vecchia

options.label: D
options.text: Italian Comedy

multiple-choice.question: What is the "rule of three" in comedy writing also known as, which involves setting up an expected pattern and then flipping it?

options.label: A
options.text: The punchline rule

options.label: B
options.text: The rule of K

options.label: C
options.text: Zig zig zag

options.label: D
options.text: The setup rule

multiple-choice.question: According to the author, what are some key elements that contribute to humor?

options.label: A
options.text: Laughter and good humor

options.label: B
options.text: Surprise and incongruity

options.label: C
options.text: Observation and imagination

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What type of comedic character is described as someone who thinks they have all the answers, often to the point of being annoying or ridiculous?

options.label: A
options.text: The doofus

options.label: B
options.text: The loveable loser

options.label: C
options.text: The know-it-all

options.label: D
options.text: The airhead

multiple-choice.question: How can you generate comedic material by shifting from observation to imagination, according to the author?

options.label: A
options.text: Drawing connections and asking questions

options.label: B
options.text: Going from "what is" to "what if" and exploring new ideas

options.label: C
options.text: Using the rule of three and the punchline rule

options.label: D
options.text: By applying the Commedia Dell'Arte rule for creating comic characters

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the "rule of K" in comedy writing, according to the author?

options.label: A
options.text: To use words that start with the letter K because they sound funny and catch the audience's attention

options.label: B
options.text: To use words that start with the letter B because they sound serious and boring

options.label: C
options.text: To use words that start with the letter T because they sound tedious and annoying

options.label: D
options.text: To use words that start with the letter S because they sound silly and absurd

multiple-choice.question: Where should you place the punchline in a comedic line, according to the punchline rule?

options.label: A
options.text: At the beginning of the line to grab the audience's attention

options.label: B
options.text: At the end of the line to create a sense of surprise and humor

options.label: C
options.text: In the middle of the line to create a sense of confusion and uncertainty

options.label: D
options.text: In a separate paragraph to create a sense of anticipation and suspense

multiple-choice.question: According to Will Rodgers, what makes something funny?

options.label: A
options.text: When it happens to a character you're writing about and you can relate to it

options.label: B
options.text: When it happens to somebody else and you can laugh at their misfortune

options.label: C
options.text: When it happens to yourself and you can laugh at your own mistakes

options.label: D
options.text: When it happens to a friend and you can share in their humor

multiple-choice.question: What is the most important rule of writing funny, according to the author?

options.label: A
options.text: To be serious and focused on the task at hand

options.label: B
options.text: To be boring and predictable in your writing style

options.label: C
options.text: To have fun and be creative in your approach to humor

options.label: D
options.text: To be sad and melancholic in your tone and language

title: The immortal cells of Henrietta Lacks - Robin Bulleri

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the HeLa cell line in scientific research?

options.label: A
options.text: It was the first human cell line to be grown in a lab for a short period.

options.label: B
options.text: It was the first immortal human cell line, allowing for repeated experiments and comparisons.

options.label: C
options.text: It was the first cell line to be used in cancer research, but not in other fields.

options.label: D
options.text: It was the first cell line to be used in genetics research, but not in other fields.

multiple-choice.question: Why do normal human cells have a limited number of divisions before they self-destruct?

options.label: A
options.text: To prevent the propagation of genetic errors that can occur during repeated cell divisions.

options.label: B
options.text: To allow for the growth of new cells and tissues.

options.label: C
options.text: To enable the development of diseases such as cancer.

options.label: D
options.text: To facilitate the testing of new treatments and therapies.

multiple-choice.question: What was the contribution of HeLa cells to the development of the polio vaccine?

options.label: A
options.text: They allowed Jonas Salk to test his vaccine by easily taking up and replicating the virus.

options.label: B
options.text: They provided a source of funding for the research and development of the vaccine.

options.label: C
options.text: They helped to understand the genetic basis of the disease, but not directly with the vaccine.

options.label: D
options.text: They enabled the development of a new treatment for polio, but not a vaccine.

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the chromosomes of HeLa cells?

options.label: A
options.text: They have the normal 46 chromosomes found in human cells.

options.label: B
options.text: They have around 80 highly mutated chromosomes.

options.label: C
options.text: They are invisible under a microscope without special staining.

options.label: D
options.text: They are only found in cancer cells and not in other types of cells.

multiple-choice.question: What enzyme was discovered first in HeLa cells, which helps cancer cells evade destruction?

options.label: A
options.text: Telomerase

options.label: B
options.text: DNA polymerase

options.label: C
options.text: Reverse transcriptase

options.label: D
options.text: Topoisomerase

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the HeLa cell line being sent to labs all over the world?

options.label: A
options.text: The world's first cell production facility was established, producing 6 trillion HeLa cells a week.

options.label: B
options.text: The HeLa cell line was discontinued due to ethical concerns and controversies.

options.label: C
options.text: The cells were used only for cancer research and not for other fields.

options.label: D
options.text: The cells were used only for genetics research and not for other fields.

multiple-choice.question: What are some of the significant discoveries made possible by HeLa cells?

options.label: A
options.text: The development of a vaccine for cervical cancer.

options.label: B
options.text: The understanding of the genetic basis of cancer.

options.label: C
options.text: The discovery of the enzyme telomerase.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: Why was Henrietta Lacks' family not informed about the use of her cells for scientific research?

options.label: A
options.text: They were not interested in the research.

options.label: B
options.text: The researchers did not think it was necessary to inform them.

options.label: C
options.text: The cells were taken without their consent or knowledge.

options.label: D
options.text: The researchers were not aware of the cells' origin.

title: Zika Virus Spreading in Most of the Americas

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of metaphors in literary works?

options.label: A
options.text: To convey complex scientific concepts and theories

options.label: B
options.text: To create vivid imagery and evoke emotions

options.label: C
options.text: To add historical context and authenticity to a story

options.label: D
options.text: To provide a summary of the plot

options.label: A
options.text: Aldous Huxley

options.label: B
options.text: George Orwell

options.label: C
options.text: Ray Bradbury

options.label: D
options.text: Kurt Vonnegut

options.label: A
options.text: Alliteration

options.label: B
options.text: Assonance

options.label: C
options.text: Consonance

options.label: D
options.text: Personification

multiple-choice.question: What is the main theme of William Shakespeare's tragic play "Romeo and Juliet"?

options.label: A
options.text: The destructive nature of love and hate

options.label: B
options.text: The struggle for power and control in Verona

options.label: C
options.text: The consequences of impulsive decisions and fate

options.label: D
options.text: The redemptive power of forgiveness and reconciliation

multiple-choice.question: Apply the concept of foreshadowing to a real-world scenario. Imagine you are planning a trip to a foreign country and you notice that your passport is about to expire. What might be a possible consequence of not renewing it in time?

options.label: A
options.text: You will have to pay a fine or penalty

options.label: B
options.text: You will have to stay in the country longer than planned

options.label: C
options.text: You will have to travel by a different mode of transportation

options.label: D
options.text: You will be denied entry into the country

multiple-choice.question: Analyze the symbolism in F. Scott Fitzgerald's novel "The Great Gatsby." What does the green light across the water represent?

options.label: A
options.text: The elusive American Dream and its promise of a better life

options.label: B
options.text: Wealth and materialism in the Roaring Twenties

options.label: C
options.text: Love and relationships in the novel

options.label: D
options.text: Social status and class divisions in society

multiple-choice.question: Compare and contrast the literary movements of Romanticism and Realism. How do they differ in their approaches to storytelling and character development?

options.label: A
options.text: Romanticism emphasizes individualism, imagination, and emotion, while Realism prioritizes social commentary, historical accuracy, and objectivity

options.label: B
options.text: Romanticism prioritizes reason and logic, while Realism values emotion and intuition

options.label: C
options.text: Romanticism focuses on the natural world and beauty, while Realism explores urban environments and social issues

options.label: D
options.text: Romanticism emphasizes the importance of tradition, while Realism highlights the role of innovation and progress

multiple-choice.question: Evaluate the impact of social media on modern literature. What effect do you think it has had on the way we consume and interact with stories?

options.label: A
options.text: It has positively influenced literature by making it more accessible and diverse

options.label: B
options.text: It has negatively influenced literature by distracting readers and promoting superficial content

options.label: C
options.text: It has had no significant impact on literature and reading habits

options.label: D
options.text: It has both positively and negatively influenced literature, depending on the context and platform

title: #TEDEdChat: A Math Class Makeover | Dan Meyer |

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary concern of the speaker about the way math is taught in the US today?

options.label: A
options.text: That students are not learning enough math facts.

options.label: B
options.text: That students are not retaining math reasoning skills.

options.label: C
options.text: That math education is not aligned with real-world problems.

options.label: D
options.text: That math education is too focused on standardized testing.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the difference between a "patient problem solver" and someone who is "impatient with ear resolution"?

options.label: A
options.text: A patient problem solver is someone who expects simple problems, while an impatient person expects complex problems.

options.label: B
options.text: A patient problem solver is someone who takes their time to think, while an impatient person rushes to an answer.

options.label: C
options.text: A patient problem solver is someone who expects problems to resolve quickly, while an impatient person expects problems to take time.

options.label: D
options.text: A patient problem solver is someone who is good at math, while an impatient person is not.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main issue with the way math textbooks are written, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too focused on real-world applications.

options.label: B
options.text: They are too focused on computation.

options.label: C
options.text: They present problems in a way that does not encourage patient problem solving.

options.label: D
options.text: They are too difficult for students to understand.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the benefit of using multimedia in the classroom?

options.label: A
options.text: It helps students to focus on a single problem.

options.label: B
options.text: It brings the real world into the classroom in high resolution.

options.label: C
options.text: It helps students to work in groups.

options.label: D
options.text: It helps students to understand complex math concepts.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's goal in redefining what a word problem is?

options.label: A

options.text: To increase the building's energy efficiency

options.label: D
options.text: To achieve net-zero energy consumption

multiple-choice.question: What is an environmental benefit of using recycled glass and other recycled materials in sustainable building construction?

options.label: A
options.text: It is more expensive than other materials

options.label: B
options.text: It has a high VOC content

options.label: C
options.text: It conserves natural resources, reduces waste, and decreases the environmental impact of raw material extraction

options.label: D
options.text: It increases greenhouse gas emissions
